title: Rwanda: Govt Mulls Over Review of Economic Growth Rate
text:
Ghana: Taking the First Step Towards Stronger Health Systems By Alex Ngarambe 
The government is considering revising the economic growth projections for this year upwards to factor in unforeseen positive economic outlook. 
The government's initial economic growth for this financial year stood at 6.5 per cent but with the performance of the first two quarters at 7.5 per cent and 7 per cent respectively, the government is mulling the revision. 
The government economic target of 6.5 per cent for this year was conservative compared with the 7.6 per cent achieved last year. 
The conservative figure for this year was as a result of anticipated slow economic activities that would not lead to a higher growth compared with last year. 
The revision of the economic growth projection was announced this week by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning during the presentation of the dross domestic product figures for the second quarter of this year. 
IMF visit 
"We are definitely putting this into account and we are working with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) who will be here next month and we should be able to know our GDP rate by the end of the year," said Claver Gatete, Minister of Finance. 
According to figures from the National Institute of Statistics of Rwanda, growth in sectors such as service, agriculture and industry have seen GDP growth surpass the initial projection. 
In terms of share contribution to GDP, the service sector contributed 47 per cent while the agriculture sector contributed 33 per cent and 14 per cent came from industry. 
In real growth, the industry sector performed better with 10 per cent growth followed by service and agriculture sectors at 6 per cent and 5 per cent respectively. 
Although there are increased economic activities, the Ministry of Finance is working with Rwanda Revenue Authority to seal revenue collection loopholes, which have seen the taxman fail to meet targets most times. 
According to the fiscal year 2015/2016, domestic resource mobilisation contributed up to 66 per cent of the budget. 
The government in this financial year is targeting to raise Rwf986 billion in domestic taxes. 
In the past two fiscal years, the taxman struggled to meet its targets partly because of dwindling revenue from international trade as well as shortfalls on the domestic front. 
In the first six months of 2014, tax and non-tax revenue collections stood at Rwf406.3 billion, five per cent below the Rwf427.9 billion target. 
However, tax experts believe that tax noncompliance in Rwanda is not alarming since there is tax system with full compliance. 
RRA is cracking the whip to recover over Rwf1.07 billion ($168 million) tax arrears not collected through noncompliance for over a long period of time. 
"No need to worry because not having tax arrears means that we have attained 100 per cent compliance which is not possible in our economies," said Angello Musinguzi, a tax expert with KPMG. 
Mr Musinguzi said in order for the revenue body to avoid losing collections, RRA should enforce tax laws, and impose heavy penalties on the defaulters. 
There should also be accuracy in tax assessment because some tax arrears are due to disputes between the revenue body and taxpayers due to inaccurate assessments and poor interpretation of the tax laws by both parties," added Mr Musinguzi. Rwanda
